label: CLIFF DWELLERS HELP THIS HERO TO ESCAPE

resource.chars:
CLIFF DWELLERS HELP
THIS HERO TO ESCAPE

One of the most interesting phas-
es of the early history of this con-
tinent is the mute record of the cliff
jdwellers, which can still be found
in tlie West. Sheer mountain walls,
seemingly inaccessible, furnished
fortresses for this ancient people,
at the top of these natural citadels.

We find a similar instance in the
monasteries of Thesally in Greece,
where monks guarded sacramental
treasures by placing them at the
top of a natural tower-like forma-
lion that rose more than 800 feet
into the clouds. The Pueblo In-
dians built terraces for the same
purpose—defense against an en-
emy who attacked from below.

This forms an important element
in tlie rousing story by Zane Qrey,
“Riders of the Purple Sage.’’ Las-
siter, hero of the novel, pursued by
twoscore ruffians, suddenly finds
himself apparently blocked by a
wall of rock. His swift vision per-
ceives foot-holes in the cliff and ho
makes his escape. A keen know-
ledge of the West enabled the au-
thor of (he book to present a uni-
que situation for the climax of his
narrative.
“Riders of the Purple Sage’’ has
been transported to the screen by
William Fox. Tom Mix, in the role
of Lassiter, will be seen in the audi-
torium tomorrow at 8 o’clock.
U. of M. 
Grace Barnes, the University Li-
brarian, attended the meeting of the
American Library Association which
was held at the Drake Hotel, Chi-
cago, from December 30 to Jan-
uary 2.
